meanings.def: a sudden increase in trade and economic activity; a period of wealth and success
examples: Living standards improved rapidly during the post-war boom.
boom in something a boom in car sales
a boom year (for trade, exports, etc.)
a property/housing boom
The boom was fuelled by accelerated demand for consumer products.
a boom in house prices
a boom in real estate
the ordinary business cycle of boom and bust

meanings.def: a period when something such as a sport or a type of music suddenly becomes very popular and successful
examples: The only way to satisfy the golf boom was to build more courses.

meanings.def: a long pole that the bottom of a sail is attached to and that you move to change the position of the sail

examples: the distant boom of the guns
The deep boom of a foghorn echoed across the bay.
The deafening boom of the explosion was heard up to 10 kilometres away.

meanings.def: a floating barrier that is placed across a river or the entrance to a harbour to prevent ships or other objects from coming in or going out
a long pole that carries a microphone or other equipment
a situation in which a period of rapid economic growth is followed by one of sudden decline
examples: High house prices encourage boom and bust and leave the economy vulnerable.
Amid the inevitable boom and bust cycle, families are facing pay cuts and job losses.

idioms.def: a situation in which a period of rapid economic growth is followed by one of sudden decline
examples: High house prices encourage boom and bust and leave the economy vulnerable.
Amid the inevitable boom and bust cycle, families are facing pay cuts and job losses.

meanings.def: to make a loud deep sound
examples: Outside, thunder boomed and crashed.
Loud music boomed from the public-address system.
A crash of thunder boomed so loudly that the floor shook.
The ship's gun boomed and the shot fell only a hundred metres away.

meanings.def: to say something in a loud deep voice
examples: + speech ‘Get out of my sight!’ he boomed.
boom (out) A voice boomed out from the darkness.
A voice from the loudspeaker boomed out, ‘Good evening, ladies and gentlemen’.
He had a booming voice.

meanings.def: to have a period of rapid growth; to become bigger, more successful, etc.
examples: By the 1980s, the computer industry was booming.
Business is booming!
The club scene was booming.
Tourist numbers have boomed in recent years.
